Award.AwardTitle: NSF Support for the 2014 USENIX Security Symposium, Financial Aid; August 2014; San Diego, CA

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant funds approximately 20 US-based graduate students to attend the 2014 USENIX Security Symposium, a leading forum for advanced professionals from academic and industrial backgrounds to meet and discuss the newest advances in the security of computer systems and networks. Participation in Security 14 and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field, and exposes students to leading work in the field. The support enables the participation of students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conference.

USENIX Security 14 will be held in San Diego from August 20-22, 2014. The conference consists of a three-day technical program, with numerous workshops co-located. The goal of the conference is to bring together researchers, practitioners, system administrators, system programmers, and others interested in the latest advances in the security of computer systems and networks. This cross-disciplinary emphasis makes it well suited as a target for student participation, and this event has always drawn a large proportion of student attendees. This venue provides an excellent vehicle for students to learn about the latest advances in computer security research, and participate in engaging discussions on a wide variety of sub-topics including network and system security, techniques for developing secure systems, technologies for trustworthy computing, hardware security, applied cryptography, etc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The  USENIX Security Symposium is the premier forum for discussing security and privacy issues. The goal is to bring together researchers, practitioners, systems administrators, system programmers, and others interested in the latest advances in the security of computer systems and networks. This year the conference received 350 submissions, representing a 26% increase over the previous year. The technical program included 67 papers. The 23rd symposium (SEC'14) was held in San Diego, CA, August 20-22, 2014. USENIX received 116 stipend applications from students, and 40 were awarded grants.  Some of the funds were covered by this award. All students attend US based schools. There was  a total of 177 student attendees. There were 646 total attendees the week of SEC ’14 and 524 attendees specifically at Security. Non-US attendees came from: Australia, Austria, Brazil, Canada, Chile, China, Czech Republic, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, India, Israel, Italy, Japan, Kuwait, Netherlands, Norway, Russia, Singapore, South Africa, South Korea, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, and United Kingdom.

The 23rd Symposium also offered a considerable amount of opportunities for students to learn, meet people, and interact. A Student/Young Professionals Meet Up was held on Tuesday evening, and was very well attended. It was followed by a Women in Academic Computing Birds of a Feather, which included many female students, and Board Game Night, which provided more opportunities to network and meet others in the field. There was also a poster session and reception which both fed the students and gave many of them the opportunity to present their research. This was followed by a Doctoral Colloquium on Thursday evening. Lastly, the papers and video of the conference talks were made available on line at the web site as part of the USENIX open access policy.

The link to the full program is found at https://www.usenix.org/conference/usenixsecurity14
